Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Neurobiology of seasonal sociality in voles
Award.AbstractNarration: Why do some species live in large groups while others interact only to reproduce? This project investigates neural sources of variation in mammalian social behavior, including pathways that support motivation to interact with others and social tolerance. Most of what is known about the neurobiology of social attachments comes from research on mothering and monogamy, while little is known about non-reproductive relationships. The goal of this project is to examine where and how the hormone oxytocin acts in the brain to influence social behavior between peers. This is approached with behavioral, pharmacological, and molecular genetic studies of meadow voles. Meadow voles display environmentally induced variation in social behavior, acting aggressive and territorial in summer months, but living in social groups in winter. These experiments will investigate how seasonal changes in neurochemistry, particularly in oxytocin circuitry, underlie changing anxiety, social tolerance, and social attachments. This fills a gap in our understanding of social relationships by adding the study of non-reproductive peer relationships, and contributes important basic information on how oxytocin contributes to both prosocial and antisocial behaviors in different brain regions. These findings will have implications for understanding sociality across social species, particularly in mammals. These studies will be conducted at a women's college, providing training opportunities for undergraduate women, many from under-represented groups. Students will serve in leadership roles and participate in all aspects of this research including presentation and publication of work. Anatomical and genomic data from these studies will be contributed to online repositories (Data Dryad and GenBank), and custom software will be made available through the lab website

POR.DRECONTENT:
For social species, peer relationships are critical to the formation and maintenance of groups. Our project investigated neural sources of variation in mammalian social behavior, filling a gap in our understanding about how peer relationships are motivated and/or tolerated.  We focused our research on the meadow vole (Microtus pennsylvanicus) — a species that undergoes daylength-mediated change in social behavior in the wild and in the laboratory.  In summer, meadow voles are solitary and territorial, but in winter they form social groups and nest with other voles.  In the laboratory, corresponding changes in affiliative behavior are responsive to manipulations of day length from long (summer-like) to short (winter-like). This plasticity in behavior within a single species allows for comparisons of molecular pathways that may underlie these behaviors across day lengths and social behavior phenotypes.

 

We established connections between seasonal changes in social and anxiety behavior.  Voles housed in long day lengths exhibited greater behavioral anxiety, increased free corticosterone, and altered CRF1 and CRF2 receptor distributions that correlated with decreased social huddling.  Furthermore, exposure to a mild stressor impaired the formation of new social partnerships.  Together these findings suggest that reduced anxiety and lowered stress axis activity play an important role in permitting social behavior and group-living in this species, and potentially others.

 

A second series of studies focused on region-specific effects of the neuropeptide oxytocin on the selective preferences for familiar social partners that meadow voles display.  Oxytocin enhances the preference for a familiar partner when infused into general brain circulation, but eliminates that preference in at least two regions that we identified: the lateral septum and central nucleus of the amygdala. Oxytocin is often touted for its prosocial effects, and these findings are some of the first to focus on social behavior effects of oxytocin outside of the nucleus accumbens and reward regions.  Importantly, oxytocin had different effects in these other regions, in all cases altering the selectivity of social behavior.  This will contribute to a deeper understanding of the role of oxytocin in social specificity, as oxytocin increases or decreases affiliation toward familiar or unfamiliar social targets depending on brain region. These findings dovetailed with a final series of studies examining season and activity-dependent changes in oxytocin production and circuitry that provided insight into the level at which seasonal regulation occurs, and how familiarity influences oxytocin release. To date, this grant has led to 11 published articles, with at least 6 more in preparation for submission.

 

Curriculum development, outreach, and training were also important goals of this grant.  I helped revise our Neuroscience major to increase course-based research opportunities, and created a new course to support this transition.  I also assisted with curriculum development and I provided visiting lectures at a local high school on an ongoing basis.  My lab shared resources we developed (including scoring software) with other labs, and increased the visibility of these resources on an updated lab website.  I also engaged with a wider audience around our research, providing interviews for articles at Scientific American, Nova online, and the Huffington Post, as well as radio interviews for RadioMD and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. 

 

The funding provided direct and indirect supported for the training and mentoring of 2 graduate students, 1 postdoctoral scholar, 2 research associates, and 30 undergraduates from diverse backgrounds. Providing research opportunities to undergraduate women at Smith College was a significant outcome of this research program, and over half of the undergraduates in the lab presented on their research at local and national meetings. 7 undergraduates conducted year-long, intensive senior thesis projects in my lab, and 9 co-authored the research articles in print (with several more planned co-authorships).  Of the students who conducted research in my lab through graduation, nearly all are now in a variety of scientific careers including research, science education, research infrastructure, and graduate programs—in large part launched by the research opportunities provided through this NSF grant.
